awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Sovereignty, Displacement, and Land Titling Strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
The increased dominance of large-scale, plantation-based production to meet global demand for commodities has contributed to the displacement of smaller communities, the loss of which has been well-documented as having adverse environmental and social impacts. Having possession of a land base is essential in order to generate revenues and prevent their own displacement, particularly for economically disadvantaged and minority communities. Legal titling and registration of those lands is often considered to be a critical method for ensuring a land base, yet titling does not always translate into real possession of those lands. Government policies, private sector forces, and natural disasters, may gradually erode of a land base as they legally or economically compel community members to sell or vacate their titled lands. Without the ability to decide who can use the lands, manage the purposes for which they are used, and enforce those policies, such communities have little security over their land bases. This project, which supports the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores how such communities establish authority over land in order to prevent their displacement. 

This doctoral dissertation research centers the experiences of nine Indigenous Rama and Afrodescendant Kriol communities in southeastern Nicaragua that received a communal title to a territory that is four-fifths the size of Delaware in 2009. This site is particularly appropriate for this project due to the recency of the issuing of a title and the researcher's engagement with these communities during a majority of the period since the title was issued, providing for an analysis of the changing conditions of territorial control since that time. While Nicaraguan law guarantees that communal lands under the title may not be sold, mortgaged, or otherwise alienated except in extremely limited circumstances and after consultation with the communities, the Rama-Kriol Territory is being impacted by mestizo settlers from the interior of the country, who are seizing growing segments of the territory for crops and ranching. This has destroyed Rama-Kriol agricultural areas and hunting grounds, contaminated rivers, and wholly displaced one Rama community. The investigation will focus on how the Rama-Kriol Territorial Government and its constituent communities are seeking to effectively use their territory through three key areas: the management of the physical occupancy of the territory; the gathering and management of information about the occupancy of the territory; and the contestation of the capacity of different levels of government to decide on the management of the territory. To do so, the researcher will interview community members, Rama and Kriol forest rangers, communal and territorial leaders, government officials, and mestizo settlers in the territory and carry out participant-observation in the daily activities of land governance in the Rama-Kriol Territory. This will allow for a fine-grained understanding of ways in which people experience and participate in these processes. Archival research at the Nicaraguan national archives will also add historical depth to this study of the processes of colonization and dispossession under way in the Rama-Kriol Territory. The resulting research products will contribute an understanding of the practices through which Indigenous and Afrodescendant sovereignty is formed and preserved, which has implications both for Indigenous and Afrodescendant peoples worldwide and for the study of sovereignty, autonomy, and state formation across the social sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In June 2023, Joshua L. Mayer completed his dissertation, "Conjuring Territory: Afro-Indigenous Sovereignty and Settler Capitalism in Nicaragua," with the support of the NSF Cultural Anthropology Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. Over the course of the funding period, Mayer worked alongside Indigenous Rama and Black Kriol communities in southeastern Nicaragua that received a communal land title for a territory nearly the size of Delaware in 2009. He was interested in the tactics and strategies the Rama and Kriol communities employed to build an effective land base in this territory amid land grabs by mestizo settlers engaged in swidden agriculture, cattle ranching, and gold mining, among other activities.

Mayer carried out this project using participant-observation, oral history interviews, unstructured interviews, and archival research between 2020 and 2023, with a lengthy pause and some remote research due to the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic. Mayer participated in the life of the Rama and Kriol communities: daily activities like cooking and cleaning, but also attending community meetings and accompanying community forest rangers on patrols. Based on community input on research plans, Mayer also conducted extensive oral history interviews with more than 80 Rama and Kriol people, assembling a body of data that illustrate community members' diverse personal trajectories, political philosophies, and visions for the future of their communities and territory. In participant observation, Mayer collected data on both the effects of loss of access to the communities' territory and the communities' efforts and plans for restoring access.

Mayer's analysis of these data, conducted in conversation with community members, demonstrate that Rama and Kriol people orient their efforts to build a land base around the idea of a duty of care for their territory, including the animals, plants, earth, and water it contains. Community leaders and groups of community members use a large arsenal of tactics to build their land base, including lawsuits, vigilance, outright refusals of state and settler authority, cooperation with government officials and settlers, and appeals to international authorities. These efforts, though sometimes at odds with one another, have allowed the communities to entangle their political and economic futures with those of settler communities, the Nicaraguan state, and international institutions. By doing so, they have contributed to their jurisdiction in their territory. These findings illustrate the creative tactics of Indigenous and Afrodescendant peoples working to build their land base under authoritarian regimes.

Beyond the intellectual contributions the data and dissertation have enabled, this dissertation research has permitted broader impacts both within and beyond the Rama and Kriol communities. First, the research has contributed an opportunity for critical reflection on visions, strategies, and individual tactics in the communities, both in individual interviews and in community meetings. Second, responding to requests from community leaders, Mayer conducted multiple trainings in interview methods with community members to facilitate their own future research. Third, the research served as a basis for Mayer's 2020 testimony before the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights and private briefings of policymakers in the United States, European Union, and United Nations. The testimony and briefings have contributed to judicial proceedings and policymaking aimed at halting the theft of Indigenous and Afrodescendant peoples' lands for illegal cattle ranching, gold mining, and other activities that produce goods that often eventually make their way into the United States.

Based on his work to date, including this dissertation research, Mayer has been hired as an assistant professor at the University of Connecticut, where he is continuing to develop his dissertation into a manuscript for publication as a monograph.
